This is a sweet little addition to Touchstone's climbing gyms (Mission Cliffs, Ironworks, etc.) and one that will hopefully take some of the pressure off of Ironworks, which can get crowded.I was disappointed to see that Great Western is pretty small.  Currently, Ironworks in Berkeley draws from two main populations:  the Cal community and Oakland hipsters.  Great Western stands to inherit half of Ironworks' customer base, but without the size to support it.  I am told that Great Western's second floor will be a massive fitness area, with a room dedicated to climbing-related exercises, but I still doubt whether that will ease the crowding around the climbing walls.The towers are really high, and the climbs are deliciously long (but that will only make the crowds that much more of a problem, since people will have to wait longer to get on the walls).   The features are probably the best part -- amazing looking cracks, crags, and overhangs.  Same goes for the bouldering area.  Great shapes and, aAs my friend Michael pointed out, there is a very secure top, which helps since the bouldering wall is a little higher than at Mission Cliffs and Ironworks.  Great Western will be my destination at off hours, when I think it won't be so crowded.  But on a weekday evening, I am guessing that I can forget about it (we'll see).

This gym is smaller than Berkeley Ironworks, but the routes go up higher and the bouldering section is larger. This gym also doesn't seem to get as crowded as Ironworks. I like the indoor bike parking, and the old smokestack gives the place character. My friend and I do wish there was a route that either went up or inside the stack though. ;)

So the shiny sparkles of new-ness are gone. What now G.W.P.C.?You're still okay by me. Climbing is aaalright, but there are a few things you can work on - You have 3 stations in the gym (squat rack, bench press and incline press) that need an olmypic bar. Yet they never seem to all be there- Your ab crunch machine has been broken for 3+ months? and counting. It's covered with dust. Try fixing it.- For god sakes, throw away stained towels... it's GROSS - Do your workers check the men's locker room? Towels on the ground  and dirty showers (not gonna go into detail here) the last 3/5 times I went. I'm not that lucky, but I sure hope it's just a fluke. You got some stuff to work on, but I still love ya GWPC. Yet I find myself driving the extra distance to go to Ironworks more often.. sorry Oakland.

Nice small gym. Climbers here seem a but more experienced than other touchstone gyms I've been to. Down side it is small but still great. Parking is not very good. I wish there were more dyno moves on their bouldering wall. Great location right off the bart station for san francisco patrons.

As a member of the family of Touchstone Gyms and having reviewed both Mission Cliffs (SF) and Ironworks (Berkeley), GWPC needs a proper review. In terms of Climbing, I feel that Ironworks or Mission Cliffs routes set harder and require a little more strength/techinque. The routes are set well and require a little more endurance. This is one my main reasons I love to climb here. You can work on your endurance on the 45ft walls and lap'em to your heart's content. The bouldering is quite interesting and somewhat over hung. Also they have a nice system board in the second floor annex which a nice plus.There is a nice up-to-date weight room with plenty of cardio equipment.   Pros:ClimbingCleanFriendly StaffCons:Parking sometimes is an issue

That pipe itself near the lead wall has got to be at least a V10. I'm a touchstone member and although Ironworks is a stone's throw away, I decided to check out GWPC last week. The walls are surely higher because I thought I had established this indifference to falling, but when I got to the top, I was damn scared. Compared to Ironworks, the gym equipment doesn't seem 10+ years old, and albeit it's smaller, I think it's worth the extra five min drive for me to go here more often.Oh, there's only street, metered parking by the way. I'd look around the inside streets for the 2hr parking. Actually, in retrospect, that's enough of a bitch for me to go to Ironworks instead. Either way, touchstone has been putting up quality gyms.

Last night was my first venture out to GWPC, and my first impression was that it's like a "hole-in-the-wall" style place - probably because architecturally it's set up in your typical narrow bay area building style with basically what looks like two long hallways that have either bouldering walls and very basic short climbs in one and belay and lead walls in the other.Now I'm a novice climber, having only gotten into this just over a month ago, so don't take my word as rote. GWPC is definitely worth a look, and if it's local, it may be awesome for you, but it defintely made me glad one of their other gyms is closer to home. My termonology may not be correct, but I think you'll get the gist. The bouldering wall is either straight up and down or has a serious overhang, with not much curvature overall. All the walls in this place seem to be taller than my normal location, which on the bouldering wall specifically I guess is to make up for the lack of interesting rock formation. This was my first time climbing on a corner, which was... abrasive... my poor fingers.. but overall the climbs are less exciting on the V0 & V1 routes. Hey, I'm a newb, that's the best I can manage, don't laugh! ;)The belay walls are really crowded from about 6pm on, and we often had to wait 5-10 minutes for a spot that I could climb. There are tons of 5.10A and above routes, but a very select few lower levels (I think I saw 2x 5.7s & 2x 5.8s. The lowest route I saw was a 5.6, so if you're truly a beginner, this won't be the gym for you. They have lower levels (I've seen down to 5.3) at other locations, but if you can't climb a 5.8, you're better off sticking to one of their other spots.I didn't check out the upstairs yet, which I hear is marvelous, and the ladies locker room was small but clean, so it seems they're on top of that. They monitor their floors a lot more than any other location I've been to, so if you don't have your belay card, you'd better get it, because they'll catch you.Overall I think I'll need to give GWPC another couple visits to have a well-rounded view of the place, but for now I'd say it's alright. It's definitely nice for those Oakland folks who've been driving to Berkeley, but I'm glad it's not the closer gym to my house.

i joined GWPC to fulfill my longstanding promise to myself to see what CrossFit is about.i *really* wanted a gym that had spinning classes and a pool, but the corporate rate was such a steal for including CrossFit classes and reciprocal membership to all of Touchstone's facilities. i figured that since no contract was required, i could bail when i feel i feel the itch to swim.so far, i'm really digging the beginner CrossFit  classes and bouldering. the walls are a bit crowded after work, but i can deal (and everyone is really nice).the gym upstairs is a nice add-on, though if i wanted just the upstairs gym, i'd probably join gold's or something.

Not only is it close enough to ride my bike to, it's the best climbing gym I've visited! It's rarely crowded, the staff is friendly and helpful, the music and the temperature always seems right. If I could, I'd take off half a star for not having enough routes at my level (just a bit beyond beginner, with short arms to boot), but there's enough variety to keep me occupied, and enough challenging ones to spur me on.

Being the closest climbing gym to me, I find myself here more than any other climbing gyms.  Driving here is such a huge pain, only meter parking and the closest residential parking is where cars tend to get broken into.  Bike here if you can.The problems here are fun but because the gym is small, it tends to get boring quickly.  If you're here with some creative friends, just make up your own problems.  With the right people, you'll find yourselves losing track of time.It gets really cold here.  To some, it's a good thing because gripping on to the holds becomes easier.Another thing that makes this place so distinguished is the training wall upstairs.  You'll see what I mean when you go upstairs to the training room.The main reason why I really like this gym is that I have not encountered any kids running amok resulting in an unsafe climbing atmosphere like many other gyms.  No one wants to fall on top of a child.

I was a member for a couple of months, and have left. This gym just never grew on me. I know some awesome climbers, but somehow I always ran into the snotty ones here. Maybe it's just indoor climbers in general. (The lack of sunlight/vitamin D indoors is my theory.) The routes themselves are OK. You can definitely start to identify the setters by how their routes are oriented for taller or shorter people. The staff was usually friendly. The locker room was usually clean. As were the gym and weights upstairs. Actually, the artwork on the walls upstairs was really well done. After thinking about it, though, it's all dark colors. I make fun of the cheesy neon gym lights at other places with the over-the-top glitz advertisements everywhere, but I now think it does make a difference in the workout. I need bright colors! I just felt sad, no matter how hard I worked out, at GWPC.And the neighborhood isn't the greatest for parking, when I had to drive. Bart is a block away, though. I think this gym is worth it for short-term training purposes. Otherwise, go outside and climb a rock!

Love this place. Great climbing routes, and the fact that it's a climbing gym keeps the weight room from getting to bro-y. Also yoga, crossfit, and a bunch of other classes. The staff are super friendly and are eager to get to know you by name. Ze'ev is a baller.

Bouldering Review: I'm in Oakland on business and stopped by GWPC for an early morning bouldering session. I come from an amazing gym, The Front, in Ogden, Utah so my expectation bar had been set fairly high. The bouldering area was pretty small but there were some fun routes. I found the taping confusing. I'd recommend using thinner pieces of tape to make it less chaotic when you're trying to find your route. I don't think they clean the holds when they change the routes, most of the feet were suuuuuper greasy. Besides those two gripes I had a great time. I climbed many of the V4-V6 routes and felt they were fairly consistent.

I really like this gym. I still go to IW, because they have more route, but GWPC has really fun, challenging routes. They have plenty of mid-range routes (5.10 - 5.11), and lots of beginner stuff too. The bouldering wall is really tall, and when I first went, the wall was really rough. It's smoothed out, and the routes are fun and challenging. The upstairs cardio/weight room is super nice and clean. All the machines are brand new and fun to use. It's great fun, and much nicer than IW. I try to do all of my cardio at GWPC because it's nicer.This place does get a bit crowded on week nights, but Saturday mornings are amazingly empty.

I like Great Western Power Company a LOT. I am a member of Touchstone, so I prefer to go to the one on Ashby (it's bigger and has a sauna), but GWPC is really close to my apartment, and I spend a fair amount of time here. There are a lot of amenities here for a small space-- bouldering and top-rope, a full gym upstairs with lots of machines and equipment, Crossfit classes, yoga classes... I've only been to yoga a few times, but I really like the Wednesday night teacher, Raven. I was there last week for a super crowded class (first class in the New Year, everyone was making their resolutions!), and she very earnestly asked everyone to make space for other devoted yogis-- and everyone responded graciously, which was awesome.GWPC gets pretty crowded during weekdays after work, but for the most part people are pretty considerate. When I first started climbing at GWPC I was a little discouraged by the small number of beginner routes, but there are a few V0s and V1s on the bouldering side as well. Now that I can climb 5.10s, I don't usually find a shortage of routes. By the way, you don't have to rent ipads as some other reviewer mentioned... it's a FREE loaner! Love that! :)

Climbing is fun. I've been climbing for about 4 or 5 months now and am a member at the Touchstone Gyms. GWPC isn't the best of the Touchstone gyms -- it isn't even close -- but the chain is well-run in general and this gym is no exception.Bouldering here isn't spectacular, but the routes seem to be changed often enough that I don't get bored. The top rope climbs are all really tall, which is my main beef with a lot of gyms. Unfortunately, they don't seem to be set as frequently as the bouldering area, so I get bored if I rope up too often. The lead area is rarely set and is definitely sub-par with regard to the other gyms in the Touchstone chain, particularly Mission Cliffs. Even Diablo Rock Gym has something unique -- a short, but seriously sloping lead wall. GWPC just doesn't stand out. All that said, it's still not bad.The fitness area, though, KILLS most other gyms. In fact, I like it a lot more than Club One at City Center where used to work out. For starters, it's nearly empty all the time. I use this space in some capacity almost every day and have only once had to wait for equipment (and not long). They have a pretty complete array of free weights and machines, making this a really great spot to be a member, even if you don't climb. Bonus points for allowing me to work out without a shirt on.

Being a beginner at this climbing rocks thing, this review might be most helpful to other newbies like myself.  Aside from a 5th grade birthday extravaganza at City Rock, GWPC is my first experience with climbing and I must say, it has been a pleasant one.  The employees, aside from one guy whose mood swings are worse than a menopausal woman, are very helpful and friendly.  Most of them do not press you with information, so if you need something, ASK.  Don't stand around waiting to be taught how to climb because you'll just look like an idiot covered in chalk.  And no one wants to be that guy.  The facility itself is clean and well-maintained (especially the bathrooms!).  Aside from all the climbing there is also a bunch of yoga classes and exercise equipment (which I rarely see anyone using...most people are on the walls like a bunch of spiders).  Basic advice if you want to get into climbing: get a bag, get some chalk, get a friend, and get ready to hate your once-useless muscles.  They are always changing up the routes so it's a different experience every time.  Technical stuff:  two parking spots right in front of the entrance are free; meters on 20th street are almost always broken, so go around the corner and there is free parking.

Compared to the other gyms, this place is okay. It's like a mediocre mix between the gym in Concord and Berkeley.This isn't something against the gym itself but more of a heads up to anyone who may read this. The gym tells you but you most definitely must bring all your valuables with you when you go to this gym. The first time I went here, there was a good amount of broken glass on the sidewalk. I'm familiar with the difference between car window glass and just normal window glass seeing as how my car was broken into the day after Fourth of July.Onto the gym. The climbing areas are pretty small. The bouldering area takes up the whole left side and the toproping gets the middle and right side. The toproping area is a decent height. Since the gym is brand new, the walls are brand new. These bouldering walls are like sandpaper and just there you up if you make the slightest mistake. Simply touching your knee or elbow against the wall is a guaranteed rip/burn. It's harsh. It's a complaint but about something that is brand new. So, hopefully now it's been worn down a little bit.Upstairs there is a full fitness center. Everything you need is provided. At the end of the second floor is a yoga room or a multi-purpose room. I don't know, I've only seen it once. And right next to that room there is a very small bouldering room where you're able to create your own problems. You might have seen them in pictures where it's an angled board with holds completely covering it. This is pretty much the only thing that makes this gym unique out of the ones I've been to that Touchstone owns.I personally like the Berkeley location better and I definitely like the Concord location more so than the Berkeley location. They have their pros and cons. However, it is still a gym to check out. I've only been there about three or four times and I think that's enough.
I love climbing here. The staff is cool and the gym never feels too overcrowded.

I usually go to the Ironworks gym in Berkeley or to this Oakland one to bolder. They both have their pros and cons, but let me focus on the Oakland one.Every time I've been here its never been really crowded. Even if there are a lot of people, I don't have to wait really long for it to be my turn. Point for GWPC.Also every time I've been there, the service is a bit obnoxious. I guess I just don't get them and their sense of humor, but it does ruin my focus when climbing. Point against GWPC.In comparison to the Berkeley gym, this one is much smaller and they don't change their problems as often. But if you like a more intimate setting for climbing, this place is better suited for you. Overall, it's clean, fun, and kinda cool.3 stars!!!

As far as public transportation is concerned this place is just a block from bart so is super convienent. the parking lot next door is only two bucks or something like that when you get it validated so that is nice since the parking here sucks if you come one a weekday. it is overall smaller than the other gyms but it is nice to be at when not crowded and the smokestack in the middle adds some charm. big lead cave and bouldering is varied. the mural that they have upstairs is awesome. more places should have murals, dammit.

I like this gym!  Although it is not as big as the other bay area gyms, it does offer some great routes and it is not as crowded as Ironworks.  The damn walls never stops, I kept thinking when is it going to end!  They are so much higher than the gym I go to in the Los Angeles area and most gyms.  The facilities are great!

As a regular at Berkeley Ironworks, I was so excited to hear about the gym opening up in Oakland, five minutes from my house.  But my first few visits were a mixed bag:  the main climbing walls have interesting technical challenges but the terrain is pretty monotonous.  I guess that's what you have to do when the floor space is limited, but it seemed heavy on the slab.  The last time I was there, the lead climbs were all really heard and the draws seemed pretty far apart.  Slab + hard routes + far-apart draws = scary combination for a new lead climber like me.  The bouldering was fun but also limited.  I am sure this is a great option for advanced climbers but, for someone at my level (10/11 in the gym), Ironworks has a lot more to offer.  I'd give it a 3.5 if I could because I am psyched to have a climbing gym in Oakland and, in all honesty, it's still 100x better than the climbing gyms I've visited in other cities.

I love GWPC. It's not as large as Ironworks, but it's awesome having a climbing gym in Oakland. I got introduced to bouldering here, and now I'm addicted.The gym is clean and it's usually not too crowded except for the post-work crowd that comes in to boulder around 6 pm-ish.I also go to a hatha yoga class twice a week with Raven, who I highly recommend. I dislike new-agey yoga teachers, and she's down to earth.For a while I stopped bouldering here because one of the staff kept playing punk and metal all the time over the sound system. Not that I'm against punk and metal, but all the time, without any variations, and in Oakland? Yikes. Not really what I want to hear when I'm climbing, it just stresses me out. These days there seems to be more variety in the playlist.There's also a comfy little lounge seating area where people sit with their laptops and use wifi. Pretty cool.One thing - if you're used to a wide variety of ages and body types at your gym, you might be surprised. The majority of people at GWPC seem to be in their 20s-30s and relatively buff. I actually prefer variety. But maybe it's a certain age range that tends to be into climbing.

A gym I can walk to!!Friendly attentive staff.  Friendliest of all the gyms I have been to in the Bay Area.  And they pay attention to the suggestion box - Yay! Muscle Milk!The holds still have some texture unlike Mission Cliffs or Ironworks.  Sometimes at those places it's like climbing polished marble.  But I haven't been to MC or IW in a while so maybe they have purchased new holds.Cleaner, better organized in terms of workout equipment  and not as dusty as other TS gyms.  Routes changed with regularity.I wish they were open later on weekends.Sauna would be nice.  Maybe a sauna and cafe on the roof?!?  Go for a climb, have a sauna, then a smoothie.

GWPC has a nice staff and facilities, but I was rather a bit disappointed with how small the gym was. There wasn't much of a range for noobs, and there were a few 5.10's, but then there were a bunch (relatively speaking) or 5.11+/lead climbs. But then I went upstairs and was floored by the fitness area. Wowzah.

If you want to get in shape fast this is the place to go. The trainers have been very professional and have continued to push me in succeeding my goals. Before i joined crossfit i couldn't even do a squat or a sit-up, but now i can do them both with ease.

Just went here for the fist time this past weekend. The trainer was knowledgeable but she yelled at me when I couldnt belay for the first time. I always have a grin on my face so she thought i wasnt being serious about belaying. I got scared a bit and felt like i was in grade school again. sheesh, chill woman. i guess she just wanted to make sure i wasnt putting my friend in danger. dude, thats my buddy up there. you think i want her to get hurt...now if it was my enemy, maybe. kidding. everyone knows i wouldnt hurt a soul. i didnt expect much so i guess it was cool. got a bit crowded around 3-4pm ish on a Saturday so i guess better to go there early. Initiation fee is $100 and $67 monthly membership available. is that steep or cheap? i dont even know. might go back but this time with no grin on my face why i belay...

This place is great.  Climbing, Crossfit, Yoga & traditional gym all in one!  The people are super cool and the membership fees are reasonable, especially when you compare to what you get here and other overpriced gyms.  I think the offerings and fair price structure reflect the future of gyms in this economy!

If you're in the downtown Oakland area, GPWC is perfect for climbing - a variety of routes, helpful staff, mellow crowd.  There's also a cardio area with the basics (just what I really need).  The women's locker room is well kept.  I'm a fan!

This review is STRICTLY for the yoga session. I've been a Touchstone member for a little under a month now and as I really like Ironworks in Berkeley, I decided to give this place a try as well. It's a lot smaller compared to the Ironworks in Berkeley - so I decided to try the yoga class upstairs. Vinyasa yoga (with the male instructor, forgot his name) was GREATTT! I've been to multiple yoga classes elsewhere before but this was was the best I've ever been to. He heated up the room b/c it was chilly in there and was an evening class, told us to introduce ourselves to the person in front of us, and hum along with him to a song we all knew. He was awesome - and definitely worth my 2 hours time!

Loved this gym!...a bit tight, but plenty tall.  Some of the climbs are integrated into the original architecture of the Power Company.  They even have iPads to use if desired at no additional charge.I wish there were better deals on 10 pack visits and/or reduction/elimination of member fees.  I would be down there quite a bit more often.

Came here after climbing at Mission Cliffs for a while just to check it out and because my membership grants me access to both.The staff was extremely friendly and knowledgable.I felt like the routes here were slightly harder than at Mission Cliffs.It was almost empty which was great for me.  Right next to BART which always makes my life easier.The workout room upstairs looked very nice although i did not use it.

I used to be a member at the Berkeley Iron Works and love that gym. The Oakland gym is much smaller and has many fewer amenities. I went there with my girlfriend who had to rent shoes and a harness. Total came to $42, which I thought was steep for such a small place. The person at the front desk did not make my girlfriend take a belay test, which I thought was a good thing at first. Later I was watching some people climb around me who did not even know how to tie a figure-8, which made me feel uncomfortable.The biggest problem was with the anchors at the top of the top roping courses. The ropes stuck so much that I was barely able to pull them though when belaying. My girlfriend, who is pretty small actually couldn't pull through some of the rope and I had to stop a few climbs half way up. I had enough when I was belaying her, went to lower her, and nothing happened! I had to throw her some extra rope, make her hold onto it and literally pull her down. We asked for our money back after this happened and left.Ratings seemed very random, some easy, some hard and route-setting appeared unimaginative.Lastly, the 150ft chimney they advertise on their website did not have any holds in it. I recommend going to the Berkeley Iron Works instead, it's only 10 to 15 minutes away.

I cam here having really high expectations because I saw that it was voted best climbing gym in the East Bay. I don't really have any complaints but I guess going there I thought it would be bigger. I liked the climbs I did there, they were really cool and I had to use a slightly different skill set from the usual climbs I do at the Iron Works which around the same level. I guess in comparison to the Iron Works, I liked the Iron Works better simply because it had way more climbs.. But this gym is still pretty solid and I'm definitely making some more trips here in the future since it's always cool to try new climbs. It also doesn't have as much traffic on Saturdays, so if that's what you're looking for this is definitely the place to go.

the newest addition to the family happens to live downtown, in oakland. i recently went here as i needed to check it out, see if it's up to snuff - and it is. there were a lot of bumps along the way to getting the GWPC up and running for the touchstone guys, but now that it's open, i might be here more often. it's great in that (and this may be due to the holiday season) not many people were present when we climbed. as much as i love sharing the joys of climbing, i also love having entire walls to myself. and the routes were set the way i like them - difficult. get here while the texture of the holds and walls is still present, unless you're too delicate that is.my two main issues with the GWPC are in the bathroom. unlike the other touchstone gyms, there is no soap in the shower. so if you need a shower, bring your own suds. also, as it's a new gym, i think they were having issues with the hot water. they had signs up that said "we have hot water" in all caps, but i couldn't seem to find any that day. the other issue that might arise is in the size of the place. GWPC is fairly small when compared with gyms like mission cliffs or concord, but it will make a nice overflow for ironworks. oh, and i didn't see any weights here..

Great addition to the touchstone climbing gyms. One membership will get you into any one of them and allow a free guest pass each month. With membership you gain access to boulder, belay, or utilize the gym and classes offered up on the second floor.  Place can get a bit crowded, so dont be afraid to throw some elbows around =) note: Ironworks in Berkeley is probably more crowded then GWPC. For us hurt folk they are well equipped with bandages, tape, chalk, etc... You can rent shoes for $4, but I would really recommend investing in your own if you plan on climbing more than once. For starters, renting can add up. Secondly, I found the rented shoes did not provide the needed support to be able to climb efficiently.  Staff is super friendly and the climbers whether beginners or advanced are accommodating and willing to help beginners and give pointers.

I have been a member of the Touchstone Climbing Gyms for several months now and I have discovered that I like going to different gyms for different services.  GWPC has, by far, the best gym that I have seen amongst the gyms.  The equipment is clean, high-end, plentiful and usually available.  The staff is always courteous.  My only warning about this location is that the climbing is more challenging here.  With limited acreage to build the gym, they built climbs that are both very tall and usually over-hanging.  The climbing, and especially the bouldering, is better for climbers who are experienced, fit and comfortable with a competitive atmosphere.  This is not to say that the staff and patrons are not welcoming to beginners, but I do believe that Touchstone has better gyms for people looking to start climbing.  That being said, you can't beat the whole Touchstone package; being able to use 6 gyms around Northern California.  I have been very happy with my membership and I recommend it to anyone.

Oaktown PC, A great climbing gym located in downtown oakland. Its residence near 19th st oakland bart is great for bike riders, skaters, runners and speed walkers like me. The smallest of the touchstone gyms, it can get a lil crowded during peak hours, luckly its also the hidden jewel of the touchstone family. Its bouldering wall space is a bit limited in size but not in challenges, and is usually saturated with alot of leet climbers. As in all touchstone gyms, PC boasts a full wieght, cardio, and crossfit gym, located up stairs. All in all I would deffinately recommend climbing here. Music is always smear worthy too.

Very fun here.  A LOT LESS busy than ironworks. I got through all the courses that I wanted to complete and more on a weekday night! WOW. There are fun courses, but the selection is more limited than at other TC gyms in the area. I really liked the crowd, the testosterone rating was within my limit. Nice change of pace from the madness that ironworks can be.

Great gym for fitness with CrossFit classes, yoga, and great cardio and weight equipment. The staff are incredibly friendly (as they are at the other Touchstone gyms as well). It is a cozy gym, which makes it a bit more difficult for climbing but still a wonderful gym. They also lend out iPads to use while working out! Been a touchstone member for several years. I've stuck with Touchstone even when I wasn't climbing. I am a regular at Mission Cliffs and Ironworks as well - both also great gyms!

GWPC is a cool new Touchstone gym, and quite a bit mellower than the others. It is nice and accessible from the 19th st. BART station, and after climbing here for an hour or two you just might look pumped up enough to intimidate your way back to the station late at night. Really though, GWPC soundly covers all the rock climbing gym basics, and its proximity to BART gives it bonus points.

I've checked out some of the other Touchstone gyms and GWPC is my favorite thus far. Besides being bikeable from my place, it also is nicely maintained, the fitness equipment is new, the women's bathrooms are clean and well stocked with shampoo and conditioner, the staff is laid back, helpful, and has good taste in music, it doesn't smell musty, and it's not hot and humid (unlike Mission Cliffs). It only gets crowded after 5:30pm on the weekdays (and usually only for bouldering) and it's never crowded on the weekends (no hordes of kids having birthday parties there either). But, because it's small, there are a lot less options for climbs so you don't get as much practice in your particular level so if you go to another gym you may be surprised to find that your 5.10A skills at GWPC only amount to a 5.9 at another gym!

Stopped by to boulder for a few hours and was surprised by the quality of the problems.  I am not much of a gym climber (love outdoor bouldering), but I must say that I had a blast and since I am soon to move to the bay area, this gym would be a welcome addition to my routine of seeking out fun and staying in shape.  Super nice staff - clean gym - not so large that you will get lost trying to find a boulder problem to suit your pleasure - and I imagine when it is raining out, this will be where I am climbing :-)

It's so so small, but the climbs are nice, the features are interesting, and the facility is nice, new, and clean. Which means that (unlike Mission Cliffs or Iron Works) it doesn't smell like sweaty climber's feet. So worth it.

It's not a best place for a beginner, 5.5-7 routes are very short and there is only one 5.8 and 5.9 (I have no idea how this is going to change in the future). If you can do 5.10 and up or want to boulder it's a great getaway from crowded Ironworks.

I like this gym a lot - I only wish it were bigger! The whole second floor upstairs is weights, cardio machines, and classroom. Downstairs is climbing and bouldering. The routes are extremely high quality - tricky problems and very interesting features on the wall, especially the dihedrals (that's inside corners and crevices). I don't particularly care for the gritty texture on the walls that roughs up shoes and skin and makes it too easy to smear your feet on the walls, but that will fade with time. It is really empty during the day, just like Ironworks, so all y'all students and artists and self-employed PLEASE get your butts to they gym between classes and leave weekday evenings to the worker bees.   Oh, and it does seem somewhat geared to higher level climbers. The lead cave is almost all hard 11s to 13s. And because of the size of the place, you're usually only going to find 1 to 3 free climbs at any given grade, whether it's 5.7 or 5.10C or 12A. Which is really limiting if you climb below 5.10. The bouldering is a bit better for variety at the easier levels.  Conclusion: This is a great place for dedicated climbers and folks who just want to use the gym equipment. Not so good for large groups of beginners or kid parties.

This is my favorite gym out of all the other Touchstone gyms. The staff is super friendly, laid back and helpful. The gym doesn't reek of smelly old socks. It's much nicer than the other rock gyms that I have been to.
so fun and addicting.  clean, friendly staff, awesome gym upstairs, not crowded.  The price is very reasonable for what you get.

My car's window was broken at the parking lot next to their building, and this seems to happen frequently (they had signs inside). I do realized that this is beyond their control, but it is definitely something to keep in mind.

gwpc is a nice addition to the touchstone gyms in the area, though i think if this were the only place i climbed, it would lack variety after a while.  the slace is cool though, and since i mostly climb at ironworks, i like the additional height and variety of having two gyms in close proximity.  the bouldering here is a little taller than at ironworks, and there is a beginner area with shorter routes graded 5.5-5.7

OMG! This place was such a stupendous disappointment. The gym here was waaay too small, and some members of the staff were ...how to put this gently...not that sharp. I'd suggest sticking to iron works.
